newsitem.title: USA: Government sees higher winter heating costs.
newsitem.headline: Government sees higher winter heating costs.

text.p: The government Friday raised its estimate for the cost of heating homes this winter because of tight fuel supplies and higher crude oil prices.

With normal weather, residential heating oil prices should average $1.06 per gallon in January-March, 10 cents higher than the same period last year and five cents higher than estimated in September for this period, the Energy Information Administration said.
But if temperatures are 10 percent colder than normal, prices could pop up another six cents per gallon, the EIA, which is part of the Energy Department, said.
Prices consumers pay for natural gas also are expected to be higher in the first three months of 1997 than in the same period last year, the EIA said.
It forecast residential gas prices at $6.29 per thousand cubic feet, up 55 cents from the same period a year ago and up 50 cents from the EIA's last estimate in September for first-quarter 1997.
Jay Hakes, EIA administrator, in a briefing said inventories of heating oil and natural gas have increased in recent weeks, which could help moderate prices.

But, he said, "This does not mean we are out of the woods because these numbers are very weather-sensitive," meaning inventories could drop on a spell of unusually cold weather, which would boost prices.
